comments.commentBody:
Daniel - you are also a shill for the CCP.

"Nazi Germany was born of democracy." Wow! If this is the double-think nonsense your dictators must spew to survive, they won't last long.

Let's try one that's just a bit more accurate: "The starvation and murders of tens of millions of Chinese - possibly more - were the direct fruits of Communism as practiced by Mao Tse-Tung, one of the most evil tyrants in all of human history."

When the day comes that you and your kind can face this ugly truth, and the damage it still inflicts on your country, there may be some hope for you.
We're far more likely to see our children caught down by paranoid gun fanatics than we are by the government.  At least that's been the track record so far.

With all respect, the Turkish protests really evince just the opposite - how much can be accomplished without guns and how much worse the situation would be if the populace were armed like Americans. I've lived in Istanbul the past five years, and currently live just a few minutes walk from the Gezi Park. Here, the overwhemlmingly peaceful protesters, armed with nothing but courage and dignity, have fought a  powerful police force empowered to brutally crack down on them to a virtual standstill. The same was true in Egypt and Tunisia, where essentially peaceful protests toppled autocratic regimes. If the Turkish protesters had guns to protect themselves and attempted to defend their freedoms with them, the violence and carnage would be unimaginable. Bodies would line the streets on both side and Turkey would be plunged into the kind of bloody civil war that it has thus far avoided. Against a far stronger and well-armed police force, the protesters may eventually have to submit, but this would be equally true in the United States, where no amount of armed citizenry would be able to resist the might of the US military or an increasingly militarized police force. Without guns, the Turks have made their voice heard as they demand basic rights and respect from their government, and that lack of guns has been a blessing for both sides, and for anyone who believes in peaceful political change.

Now you know why millions of Americans have an unflinching belief in the right to bear arms. Oh sure, this can never happen in the good old USA. That's because we are armed to the teeth. Governments should have a healthy fear of its populace, for without said fear you are a heartbeat away from losing the meager freedoms you enjoy.

What we are really witnessing is a war at large in the Islamic world between Sunnies and Shiites On the one hand Shiites are led by Iran. In the opposition, supporting Sunnies, you will find Al Qaeda and affiliates in the battleground with money pouring from the Arabian peninsula.

Perhaps, the US remain under the illusion that that they are strong moderate and West friendly leaders in any of these countries that the US could readily support. There aren't. It is clear that the Islamic world, Sunni or Shiite, in general, rejects Western values and despises Western influence and US support of Israel.

So why support either group that despise you?

The answer is, or it should be, that the overriding priority of the US is to weaken Iran and its sphere of influence. Let's not forget that the end result of the Iraqi war was to put Iraq in Shiite hands and therefore, in the hands of the Ayatollahs of Iran. So taking Syria away from Iran's sphere of influence is the overriding priority of US Foreign policy. What comes next in Syria, as long as it opposes Iran is a victory for the US.

The crackdown didn't cause China's current economic auccess, nor would political liberalization have prevented it. China had the right ingredients at the right time. It provided a large labor market open to foreign investment. Your psotions suggest only bloody, iron-fisted dictatorships can produce economic success. However, plenty of dictatorships have adopted poor economic policies that lead the country to ruin (Mao and Gang of Four  era China did pretty poorly,) while other countries have managed economic success without an oppressive regime.
I agree it was a bloody event. But I believe the crack down here refers also to the de-liberalization after the massacre.

To BR:

How about a government that machine guns and bombs other country's citizens, and does nothing to prevent its citizens from being machine gunned by crazies? Tiananmen is a tragedy, but you are just throwing out words without thinking.

Digenis, the city's name is Istanbul.  If I were you, I would first mind the collapse of the Greek state before worrying about Turkey and Istanbul!  Having said that, I truly hope things are getting better for Greece.  You don't deserve the humiliating treatment you are getting from the EU and especially Germany.

Erdogan has become unhinged a few years back after he was stricken with prostate cancer as an explanation.  A few years back Erdogan was stricken with prostate cancer and underwent a radical prostatectomy in Konstantinople.  The operation severed the neurovascular bundle that provides the electrical stimulus for erections, and caused complete; permenant, and irreversible impotence.  Viagra does not work,  The only solution is the implantation of a plastic or inflatable penile prosthesis, a poor solution at best.  All the lion-like roaring by Erdogan is but a futile, vain, petty attempt to compensate for his impotence and an effort totransform from a hanoum to a mensch again
i thought the people in beijing were supporting the students, feeding them on their way to and from the square.

Quoted the words of Deng Xiaoping, Deng said to prepare bloodshed and would make for the worst, ready to sacrifice themselves and their families lives, prevent demonstrators out of control, like a tragedy to become the Cultural Revolution, avoid letting China into chaos.

Chinese leadership who made a mistake during Tiananmen Square incidence was not communicating with students immediately as sentiment against Chinese official corruption was high. Nonetheless, at the time then Chinese leaders, Mr. Zhao and Mr. Li begged students with expressing and intentional compromise in dialogue with students yet students had been totally manipulated by out side forces as evidence shown and discuss as following:

1) Where was mass financial monetary coming from to support mass students, who sat in at Tiananmen Squire for almost three months with germ developed into Tiananmen squire?

2) As mass monetary support from outside force, students underwent change from original position of free from Chinese official corruption to come into corruption themselves. They jockeyed for the power and kidnapped other student leader due to power struggle for the student leadership. As per a Canadian journalist claimed that she could not see a student leader for her interview without through a layer and layers of bureaucracy. If this was what then students in their mind that Chinese leadership would look like, a monarch of emperor and bureaucracy, it would not be the best interest of China.

"America - Big Army that's more for show than go."

I dunno – seems to me our big army actually shows up in a lot of countries.
You don't notice what a name symbolizes, but you'll happily judge people on the sorts of names they choose for their children?

In our recent big annual deficits, the Federal expenditure was about 25% of GDP (while revenues were as low as about 16% of GDP).  In normal times in the Clinton era, it looked like we had a decent society with the federal government spending at about 20% of GDP.  We should tax, progressively, to have revenues of 20% of GDP, and that goal determines the top tax rates.  If not 20% then 23% or whatever number the nation comes to a consensus on. The Rawlsian argument is flawed.
Aren't trendy names, by definition, common?
I have sensitive skin as well. I used to use Clarins but now I use CeraVe am facial moisturizing lotion. It works well and is much less expensive.  No breakouts from this.
I get the impression that scads of commenters somehow have equated "having a life" with criticizing others on the Internet. I freely admit I do have no life, but I wonder at their hypocrisy.
Perhaps less than you think. All of that will probably take place online or by thought transfer or something.

You've evidently missed the trend of naming boys after pre-industrial occupations.

Cooper, Carter, Mason, Chandler, Sailor.

I know, so 10 years ago.

Although I still like the name Rufus for a redhead. Bruno is a great name. Flavius for a blonde, not so much.
Of course Molly now is the nickname of a common street drug, so maybe that's not such a great idea.

Funny, I work in a school with a Krish, and Elver, a variety of Kayleighs, and no one feels sorry for anyone. Welcome to the new reality. There is no such thing as  weird name on the playground anymore.
So, basically you're saying that you are a mannerless person?

And of course "Caitlin" is just Kathleen in Irish, pronounced exactly the same.

Except in America, where it is pronounced Kate-Lynn.
Allison is a boy's name, dearie, and everybody knows Jennifer is only appropriate for the heroines of old-fashioned English novels.

In addition, many of the critics of earlier experts that you mention (i.e., the ones showing that expertise is "bogus") are playing the easy game of sitting at a later time and judging anyone who didn't predict the way that things actually turned out to have been foolishly wrong. On obvious criticism of this is that it mixes together things that should be distinguished: it is perfectly fair to judge stock-traders or policy experts on their ability to make money and prevent disaster. But that is a far different matter than judging earlier philosophers, authors, visionaries, and so forth.

Second, this reveals the most basic violation of proper historical method, because there isn't the slightest attempt to understand what experts in earlier time could and could not have known, or how remarkable it was that some people could form a powerful conception of what might come to pass, given the blindness about the future that envelopes every era. For example, one can easily laugh at Newton for believing that there was a universal ether, that the sun was the center of the universe, and so forth, if one ignores the obvious fact that he got a stupendous amount right, laying the basis for modern physics, and he created the most important revolution in scientific knowledge for several hundred years.

When my son was born in 1964 we named him Mark--we liked it and it was fairly uncommon. Move ahead a couple of years and it seemed every other boy was given the name. I've always liked the classic names, David, Stephen, Patrick, but if you yell any one of those names at family functions several people answer.

I consider myself so fortunate to have a name that is both rare and beautiful. (I can count on one finger the number of people I know with the name Marjorie.) Very few people call me Marjorie, but I still love it and thank my oldest brother for suggesting it.

Is it possible these names sound funny, weird or awful to our ears because we associate them with elderly or middle-aged people? Won't that one day be the fate of today's Masons and Chloes?

You summed it up there. Name fads are nothing new, and each generation of grandparents has been aghast with shock at the absurd and idiotic names their offspring came up with. One can only hope that most of them, unlike the GIFT-y posters here, had the good manners and taste to keep their personal judgments to themselves.

Overly self-involved. Besides, classics are back. This feel just like another form of bride-zilla wedding mania born out of hyper competitiveness and insecurity.
In your attempt to be oh so unique you've become cliche. Ugh.
